ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None!
none
Live virtual lecture on some days and recorded on others
Flipped classroom recorded lectures on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course really helped me to develop my conversational skills in Spanish, taking much of what I have learned and combining it into a class that focussed more on applying knowledge and studying culture. My Spanish improved massively from taking this class.
Lots of spanish skills
A good amount of practice speaking Spanish.
Most of the grammar needed to become fluent in Spanish. Subjunctive, conditional, all past tenses, future, etc.
Spanish speaking skills, learned about Spanish culture

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course's main strength is that it requires you to be constantly engaged with the language throughout the entire semester, in a variety of different activities including podcast-making, writing, making videos, etc. Given this, however, the course had a lot of work on a nightly basis. It often seemed excessive, and speaking with other students who took the class before it seems this may be due to the online situation, as it was not like this for them.
The course was just so much work for being online it was kind of ridiculous
I think the class occurring so often helped keep students engaged with, but at times there was smooch work for one night that it was hard to do any of it thoroughly.
Solid curriculum that uses diverse methods to drive home the grammatical concepts: short stories, podcasts, cultural projects, supersite homeworks

Too much homework at times. 

Very great engagement by professor with students.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the seminar format worked perfectly, and the Zoom breakout rooms were helpful as tools to engage 1-on-1 with other students and develop conversational skills.
It was good but too much
I believe the create-your-own podcast project was a new assignment because of the online format; it was helpful in practicing speaking out loud and more fluidly.
Zoom class meetings were great. Breakout rooms functioned well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would, as I think it was definitely geared to vastly improve our Spanish and have us learn to be more fluent in conversation. The activities, both in-class and for homework, were very engaging and diverse. It should be noted that there is a lot of work though, and this made it difficult given the number of classes I took. It runs like an intensive Spanish course, so I would just recommend that anyone who takes it be ready for that.
Yes if they want to die in work
Yes if you want a lot of practice with Spanish, no if you do not want to spend a lot of time on it.
Yes. There is more workload than L3 but the curriculum is solid.
Yes!
